print_settings.Notes:: PLA - flexible enough for the bowl to shape as required by the legs

description.text:
8-sided spiral bowl, with four press fit legs.
Bowl body prints flat, as large as your printer base will allow.
Four legs printed separately, then press fit into place under the bowl body.

180mm diameter - could be bigger, but depends on the printer bed.

Printer:

3D Stuffmaker Prusa Explorer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

PLA - flexible enough for the bowl to shape as required by the legs

Designed and then trialled with 3Doodler

I have seen a wood trivet made with a spiral cut, which is flat until you move the lever up to convert it into a bowl. I wondered if this could be done with 3D printing.

I sketched out my design, then I trialled the concept with a 3Doodler 3D pen, and it seemed to work.

Finally, I checked out Thingiverse for spirals, and there are all sorts of spiral creating tools and customizers available. This is based on a spiral from one of the customizers.

Try different legs with this bowl - two types of curved legs are available at:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1985638 - Curved Legs Mk1
and
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1985645 - Curved Legs Mk2

The different shapes to the legs will alter the shape of the bowl !

comments.text: I think it is similar as the rainbow sweet bowl in so far as it is a bowl. There is an STL files for each layer of the rainbow bowl, where my bowl has the one spiral STL file for the main bowl. Sort of different. Thanks for looking at my design.

et soit reprendre les vis d'origine ou des plus longue pour la fixation sur le chariot ,cela dépendra de votre montage .

Hello,
Here a cable path, specially made for ZONESTAR P802Q steel.

the small chute is not terrible but do his job, I would take the maybe later.

must be 31 links to the ideal length.

2 x14 M3 screws for mounting on the motor bracket

1 M3 x 20 to set the chute

and either take back the original screws or longer for mounting on the carriage, this will depend on your installation.

title: Single space LED guide for Universal Light Bridge

description.text:
Instead of ordering an arduino and using a strand of LED's that were a single color I decided to go with an LED strip that used RGB lights and is connected via Bluetooth so I can control everything from my phone / tablet.

The original LED guide made way for two strips with a divider down the center, this one brings it back to one LED strip with a wider 14mm width. The LED strip I ordered is below and was 13mm wide.

http://www.bestbuy.com/site/playbulb-6-56-comet-led-light-strip-multicolor/4310500.p?id=1219726219875&skuId=4310500

description.text:
Update (1/16/18) - I will be doing some new video tutorials on how to build this project from start to finish including a live stream on YouTube of a full build from start to finish. Please make sure you follow my accounts to keep up-to-date!

Discord - https://discord.gg/N3Mk6Hp
YouTube - https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCksXxoSI1yyZQFIKy5tUZaw
Etsy - https://www.etsy.com/shop/3dprintspace

Update (8/27/17) - It's finally here! A working image file of Retropie 4.2 working properly with the Pi Zero W enabling onboard wifi and bluetooth! This image has been setup for the 3.2" PiTFT (although it will work with others) and enabling the I2S amplifier for proper audio from your Pi. I've also added a new theme that works much nicer with smaller screens, which will be easier to see the menus. Please let me know if you have any questions, but if you plan to make any PiGRRL Zero (Plus or non-Plus), this is the only image file you'll need!

Custom Retropie 4.2 IMG File Link:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/xbyz6ybmli6w0cb/Retropie4.2-PiGRRLZeroPlus.img?dl=0

The PiGRRL Zero, but with a much larger screen!

This is the remix of the original PiGRRL Zero and a variation of the PiGRRL Zero that I recently designed to include an amplifier, external speaker, and standoffs to hold the case together (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1621907).

This remix of PiGRRL Zero modifies the case size horizontally approximately 0.5" to accommodate a much larger screen. The screen has been upgraded from 2.2" to 3.2" utilizing the 3.2" PiTFT screen from Adafruit (https://www.adafruit.com/products/2616) and wide face tactical buttons for the PiTFT (https://www.adafruit.com/products/1489)

This design still runs off the Pi Zero which is attached to the back of the PiTFT, just like the original build. You will have to do some modification to the PiTFT and the Pi Zero to make this configuration work, including directly attaching the wires from the PCB's to the Pi Zero GPIO ports. I have several tutorial YouTube videos showing how to complete this build, including some tips and suggestions, so please refer to those in the links attached below.

You'll also need to rotate the screen because it defaults differently than I have it in the case. Go ahead and use linux commands to modified /boot/config.txt and at the very end add "display_rotate=2". Here is a link to a forum article that explains how to do this. - https://www.raspberrypi.org/forums/viewtopic.php?f=78&t=110948

Guidance Videos:
Helpful Video 1 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WRJmxOPdGIw
Helpful Video 2 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SJauBY24Ixg
Helpful Video 3 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OaYaq0P4i_g
Final Build Video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kLe9Dj7uI90
PiTFT Update - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zSWCRU0AIOM

If you want me to print you a case, go ahead and hit me up on my Etsy shop. I have this setup and tuned to print very nice versions of this case. If you have a certain color you want, just submit an order and I'll pick up some filament. If you want me to build one of these from scratch for you, hit me up on my Etsy shop. I have a listing that you can purchase one, and I'll assemble it with the color you want.

Check out my multicolor button for the PiGRRL Zero and Zero Plus if you are interested in that - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2368254

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.16

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Just rotate to make the faces on the bottom.

4 x Tactile Switches for 3.2" PiTFT (https://www.adafruit.com/product/1489)

1 x Tactile Button switch (6mm) x 20 pack (I use the soft buttons, look those up on Adafruit)
2 x Shoulder Button Tactical Switches (http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/ALPS/SKPDAMD010/?qs=N5Jky1br14NSNdc2t0sRXg%3D%3D)
1 x 2500 mAH Lithium Ion Battery (https://www.adafruit.com/product/328)
1 x Breadboard-friendly SPDT Slide Switch
1 x Adafruit I2S 3W Class D Amplifier Breakout - MAX98357A
1 x 10K Ohm 5-Pin Dual Linear Dial Wheel Potentiometer 16mmx3mm (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B013FPKCMM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

comments.author: DTEAM

comments.text: Another question (I'm full of great ones): Who's the originator of this audio circuit? I've noticed multiple projects use it, and they all have the "SD" pin connected to 5V. According to the doc for that audio board, that would only give you the left channel. If you leave it disconnected, that 1Mohm resistor on the board between SD and Vin should give you a stereo average of both L and R, which I think would be preferable to just dropping the right channel on the floor.
comments.author: FarrisGoldstein

comments.text: I put together the audio with help of another person. I believe most games were mono setup so it didn't matter if it was stereo or just the left channel only. However, I think you are correct that you can add stereo pretty easily with a 1Mohm resistor on the board between the SD and the VIN. Let us know if you tackle the project!
comments.author: FarrisGoldstein

comments.text: Just FYI, the board itself already has a SMT 1Mohm resistor between SD and Vin, so to get the stereo average, you just disconnect SD altogether. I tested and verified that earlier today, by playing a wav file with discrete L and R channels. With SD tied directly to Vin, only the left channel was coming through. With SD not connected, both channels came through the mono mix.
comments.author: 3dprintspace

comments.text: Also, has anybody done any power optimization work? Seems that the whole thing at idle draws a little but more than the 1A power module can supply, so if you play while plugged in you will still eventually drain the battery.
comments.author: FarrisGoldstein

comments.text: I apologize for bugging you again with this but I ran into a bit of a snag with the soft tactical buttons and was wondering what I did wrong or if you experienced the same issue. Even after straightening the pins on the buttons the foot print is too large for the pcb so the buttons sit a bit taller than the originals and if I mount them on the same standoffs they are essentially depressing all buttons at once with very little travel left when assembled. I am sure I could adjust the dpad and buttons files to compensate but I wanted to double check with you first and verify I am not missing something. Thank you again!!!
comments.author: 3dprintspace

comments.text: You have to compress the pins and buttons onto the PCB much tighter. The button should be almost flush with the PCB. The pins always hold up well for me, so don't worry about damaging them. If you have already soldered the buttons to the PCB, go ahead and use some needle nose pliers and grab the side of the button to compress it to the PCB, should work like a charm.
comments.author: AjaxSliguy

comments.author: Zophael

comments.text: A month late, but I just saw your comment as I am printing the top half of this case on my MP mini right now. I agree with Jpete24, the case doesn't print well split (at least for me, I tried it with the Adafruit case, "welded" the two halves together, and lots of sanding, but still a terrible fit). What I ended up doing for the original Adafruit case, and this one is positioning it on my bed at a 45 angle with supports, and a brim (only 5 lines of brim on original case, 2 on this one). I also had to make sure that in Cura my bed was set to 123mm in the x and y to make full use of it. You end up with a fair amount of support material, but only under features of the case, so it is spread out, but I recommend situating it with the inside of the case facing the build plate, as Cura will want to make a few extra support structures for the various button and board mounting posts. As an added bonus in my case, a slightly wobbly z axis, and the choice to print it in wood filament, meant that after a light sanding, and a few coats of stain, I have what looks like actual wood grain, I couldn't be happier (hopefully my zero plus case turns out just as well)
comments.author: Zophael

comments.text: I can try to look into splitting the case, but from I saw from Noe at Adafruit, it wasn't super easy to find a spot that keep it structurally sound.

One aspect I am looking into is if it is possible to use I2C or SPI for the buttons to allow the touchscreen to still function, but that is more of a wish then a need.
comments.author: DreadPirateMike

comments.text: You're basically going to build a horizontal PiGRRL 2. I've looked into it, but scraped the project only because the Pi Zero uses 1/3 of the power of the Pi 3. You stick a Pi 3 in that thing, you'll need at least a 6000mAh battery to keep up with the power demands. I would look into the battery life of a PiGRRL 2 before you dive too far and regret it. I'd stick with the Pi Zero. The only thing that the Pi 3 can do better is N64 and Playstation games. Pi Zero's can handle about anything you throw at it.
comments.author: DreadPirateMike

!UPDATE! - 12 March, 2017

I have updated the original case to have holes in the bottom for better air circulation. I have also added a second case that fits the larger ReadyMadeRC 1500mw 1.2G VTx.

Approximate VTx dimensions-
Small VTx - 25mm x 50mm x 10mm
Large VTx - 25mm x 70mm x 10mm

This simple video transmitter case houses the 400mw & 800mw 1.2G Tx's found at many RC sellers. One such seller is ReadyMadeRC.com. These transmitters come enclosed in a very heavy aluminum heat-sink case which can be discarded.

Simply cut a rectangle in the wing or fuse foam and glue the case in so the cover is flush. Tap the corner holes for a 2mm screw and you are ready to go. You can also add a pair of lightweight 22mm square heat-sinks (see picture) which only add about 8g.

title: FT Kossel 2020 - 80mm RAMPS Cooling Fan Bracket

description.text:
This bracket holds an 80x25mm fan in place underneath a Folger Tech Kossel 2020 in order to cool the controller board (RAMPS etc). This was necessary for me to use the heated bed without the controller throwing a fuss (in my case the printer was throwing an "Extruder MINTEMP" error when the bed was heating).

It mounts to the acrylic that supports the heated bed and controller boards. The acrylic slots between the edges of the bracket and is held in place via a friction fit, and the fan is mounted underneath the printer at a 30deg angle from vertical.

Note that in order to add an 80mm fan (for reference, I'm using a CoolerMaster Blade Master 80), the printer must be raised somewhat to allow clearance. I'm using something like these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1313461 Also, make sure you cover all ports between your controller board support and the heated bed (that's what all the Kapton is for in my photos)--otherwise the fan will cool the heated bed so that it won't get to 100C (on 12VDC anyway). See installed photos for example.

Sorry I don't have any very visible as-built photos; hopefully the as-installed photos showing the bracket and fan under Kapton tape and supplied renderings shed light on things.

description.text: This is a simple object to assist in finding real-world offsets between nozzles on a multiple-toolhead machine. We can usually know the designed offset, but (especially with hacked things) the precise distance tends to vary.

Change the offset, repeat!

description.text:
The Archimedes screw is a device believed to be invented by Archimedes, one of the world's greatest scientists, in the 3rd century B.C. It was most often used to transport water from lower ground to higher ground for purposes of irrigation, flood prevention, and more. Interestingly, it is still used today in many different applications.

In this lesson, students are tasked with moving different materials up an incline using an Archimedes screw. This project is intended for high school engineering or physics students, though can be scaled back to use in lower grades as well.

Here's a video of the sample file included, showing how a basic Archimedes Screw works: https://youtu.be/dqR61dKTcHE?list=PLvy119PeSK5gUZak-0c0tqIgpWvGlED39.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:
  • Each Blade part is only ~5 in tall. Print more than 1 if you want to make a long screw and connect them with the BladeConnector and some glue (the sample shown is 3 sections)
  • You don't really need to print out CaseTop unless you plan to enclose the screw
  • You could likely use something non-printed (PVC tube or similar) in place of the CaseBottom to save some printing time
  • Bottom Adaptor needs to be printed with support material. All other parts should print well without supports.

The sample file included was designed in OnShape. If you would like students to start with this design, I made the file public here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/45a752c603d10bb34fbe1e34/w/dde73d88c67e0cad91526961/e/9796c97fe0b7b2fd3907f5c9.

If students are starting from scratch, you can use any design program you want (as long as it’s capable of making helixes).

If you don’t want to involve 3D design in this project, here is a great Customizer design that allows you to create a custom screw without needing to actually design it: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:96462.
NGSS

Background The Archimedes screw is a device believed to be invented by Archimedes, one of the world's greatest scientists, in the 3rd century B.C. It was most often used to transport water from lower ground to higher ground for purposes of irrigation, flood prevention, and more. Interestingly, it is still used today in many different applications. Well before power tools were created, people had to create clever uses of common materials to make their work more efficient. The Archimedes screw is one example of this type of simple machine. A basic screw consists of a screw (helical spiral part), a tube (full or partial), and a crank. Using only human input (rotating the crank), you can move large quantities of material up an incline much more efficiently than simply carrying it. See a great video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A-xPRbj88V4 All archimedes screw designs have the same basic components, but can take many shapes and sizes depending on the application. In this activity, students will create (or modify) an archimedes screw to efficiently transport material from lower ground to higher ground. Objectives Students should walk away with knowledge of:
  • History of the Archimedes Screw
  • Engineering principles of an Archimedes Screw
  • Fundamentals of parametric 3D Design
  • Understanding of design parameters effect on performance
    • Audience This activity was designed for an 11th - 12 grade engineering or physics class.
  • If students will be designing their own screws, they should have a solid foundation of 3D modeling skills. Alternatively, you can use a Customizer model or start with the OnShape example included with the lesson (more description of this below).
    • Skills Learned High School
  • HS-PS3-3 - Design, build, and refine a device that works within given constraints to convert one form of energy into another form of energy.

Preparation Set up the lower and upper basin and fill with water (1 for each group would be ideal, but 1 setup for the whole class works too). Day 1 - Student planning
  • Students should measure the basins, the distance needed to cover, and begin planning their screw design.
    • Day 2 - 6 - Student design, print, test, iterate. Given then these are large prints, emphasize that students test small sections first before printing out their entire assembly. More detailed notes on the sample design below. Day 7 - 8 - Finalize design, complete assembly and test. Students should finalize and assemble their full designs and get in last minute tests before the official testing. Day 9 - TEST! Each group should demo their design by showing how much water they can transport from the lower basin to the upper basin in 30 seconds. Day 10 - Reflection Discus the different designs. Which worked best? Which adjustments proved most effective? If you were to re-design, what would you change? Optional Extension Activity Provide each group a different material (i.e. honey, cheerios, etc.) to have them think about what modifications would need to be made to accommodate these different materials.

• 2 bowls (lower and upper basin) - I used 2 clear chip bowls
  • Computers - Access to computers with 3D Design program of choice installed (I used OnShape - more on this below)
  • Plenty of filament - Student designs will be 3D printed and will likely take several iterations. Try to group prints together and utilize overnight printing if possible.
  • Glue - for assembling the screws. I used just used super glue.
  • Water
  • Optional: Other material for students to move with their designs (i.e honey, cheerios, gravel, etc.)

• http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-an-archimedes-screw.htm
  • http://www.famousscientists.org/archimedes/
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:96462
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79245
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42755
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:656194

Below is a breakdown of the sample file included in the Thing Files. The sample file included was designed in OnShape. If you would like students to start with this design, I made the file public here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/45a752c603d10bb34fbe1e34/w/dde73d88c67e0cad91526961/e/9796c97fe0b7b2fd3907f5c9.

Part diagram (not pictured: case front and spill plate) Blade Connector (green part) allows you to connect multiple blades together to make long screw designs. It's also used to attach the crank to the top blade. Blade Profile sketch. 65 degree angle allows for printing without support material. Helix sketch defines the pitch of the blade. I used the Sweep Tool to create the blade. Blade 1 created using the Sweep Tool with the Blade Profile Sketch and the Helix sketch. Copied and rotated Blade 1 by 180 degrees to create Blade 2. Editing the Helix sketch is a quick way to dramatically affect your screw. In this case, I reduced the pitch to create a tighter screw. Updated screw after reducing the pitch. Experiment with the space between the blade and the Case to minimize water loss. Video of the Sample Screw in action

description.text:
Ok, i didnt even build Mk1, i had a better idea.....Go lower.
So i put the esc's on the arms, and the electronics in the middle. Now the battery can be on the main plate where it should be.
I added a space underneath for power cables and a pdb. This is the "power deck". It has the original upper plate as the bottom plate, supporting "robopower.stl".
The power deck has spaces for a noise filter, and 2 bec's, one 5v for the fc, and one 8v, or 12v for video. I will use the 6.5mm spacers for this setup.
You could put a normal pdb in there if you like, just select the 4.5mm spacers, as most pdb's are 2mm thick.
Put 2 of the 8mm spacers at the back.
Now you have space in the center fo the flight controller, the VTX and the RX.
"Robofront2" fits a HS1177 camera. "Robofront3" fits a board camera. It has small walls to help keep the battery in place during a crash, "Roborear2" is really just for this purpose alone and has no other function.
Both the front and rear are fixed in place with 25mm standoffs. See the build photos in the post printing section. You will need 4x 30mm m3 screws to put it together, or be clever and cut some screws to make m3 studs.
I would finish off this build with these skids by PeteDee: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:810325

Printer:

Malyan M150 and Mini Fabrikator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The only part that needs support is the front, turn it upsidedown so you need less support, it will print quicker. Choose support everywhere, so the camera mounts get support.

Im using my homemade pdb and some voltage regulators. Like this, 30mm screws front and rear. Underneath with the spacers and power deck All the essentials go in the middle deck, see the 30mm screws come through. Put the top deck on, and some 25mm standoffs on the 30mm screws. Im using a big 65c battery, i have 2306 motors, it needs the power. Holes in the top for screwing onto the 25mm standoffs.

author: mnellany

description.text:
So this is my third attempt at making a way to wrap headphones. This version puts the least amount of stress on the ends of the cable. This is also the least practical design in my idea, but I think its more of a novelty item.

Assembly:
1 End Link
(As Many as you need) Main Link
3 Clips

-Attach a clip to both earbuds, and the end of the cable.
-Snap together all of your Main Links, then add the End Link

-The End Link Should be printed in a different color than the rest so that you can tell where you can take apart the bracelet.

I will make a video for this design if there is enough demand

author: mnellany

title: Eye In Stein - A 3d printed desktop pun

description.text:
Eye in Stein - a cringe worthy 3d printed pun.

With this little trinket you can accomplish two goals:

  1. Draw inspiration from the great thinker
  2. Chase away co-workers, friends and family with a painfully bad 3d printed pun.

Slicer Note: Slic3r didn't work well for this. ffslicer worked great for me.

Disclaimer: Do not use this vessel for food or drink.

Printer:

PowerSpec Ultra 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

20%
I used white paint on the eye ball and a black sharpie on the pupil. Add little red veins with a thin sharpie if you really want.

author: Jimbotron

description.text: This is not an item for 3d printing. I designed this primarly for the fun of doing the design and the fact there is not alot of pellet makers out there. First step after parts have been created by you local metal shop. Based without the nut attached or the long hex-screw in it (long hex screw is just for keeping whole kit together), place on a table. Next you put mold parts 1,2 and 3 together and use guide poles to get them in place, make sure to orient all pieces correctly or springs on base will miss spring holes. Next you place fill plate on top and again make sure to orient properly, shouldn't be hard hole for long hex-screw should be guide. Remove small hex-screws from fill plate and attach main nut, screwing down until molds are just touching the start of the rim on the base, you can screw in the long hex-screw to keep everything oriented. Next is to pour hot lead into the eight fill holes, check lead escape holes on side of molds to see if fill was good. After filling and with long hex-screw removed, take lid (with deer facing toward fill plate) and tighten down nut as far as it will go and then remove the nut. Then reverse the lid, orient properly, again use long-hex-screw hole for guidance, turn everything upside down and give base shove onto the lid so the small guide holes in lid and push back the larger guide holes of the fill plate or the next step will not work. With lid (deer again toward fill plate) attach small hex screws and tighten them down. This should have lid attached to fill plate and with a good turn break off the excess lead. Remove small hex screws, give whole thing a good shake and pry apart the molds if necessary cause you are done.

Directions for use:

  1. Place the cork in the Corker.
  2. Place the cup into your corkscrew and clamp on.
  3. Insert the corkscrew fully into the cork.
  4. Pull the cork from the Corker.
  5. Place your bottle into the corkscrew.
  6. Push the cork into the bottle.
  7. Release the clamps, and rotate the bottle until the corkscrew leaves the cork.

This needs 12 steel BBs. Standard size for those is 4.57mm or 0.18 inch.

Either print the complete bearing with cage or if you want to print the cage in a different material, STLs of the races and cage separate are provided.

I didn't put a hole through the middle, use your favorite 3D modeling or CAD program to punch whatever size/shape you want.

To assemble, place the inner race inside the outer race.
Push the inner race to one side. That gives enough gap to insert the balls.
Evenly distribute the balls and center the inner race.
Snap the cage into one side, between the balls.

Hopefully all 12 BB's can be inserted. Might need to change the design to a larger diameter so there's more space between the BB's.

Commercially made bearings are made using this procedure, with specialized equipment to shift the races, insert and distribute the balls then snap in a plastic cage or rivet or spot weld a two piece metal cage.

title: Hammerhead Magnetic Carriage for Delta printers

description.text:
I have designed a new mag-ball carriage. I named them the Hammerhead because they look kinda like the shark... :)

With the old design, i lost 10mm of my build radius. (20mm in both directions) That was too big of a hit on my build plate. These are designed to give that space back; with maximum arm travel.

I printed them out of ABS with a 100% infill and a 2mm wall. They need to be rock solid. Any flex and the prints will come out looking bad.

There are 3 types of STL files attached. One is a complete build. The others fit together with some glue. I used "ABS Juice" as my glue. Make sure they fit together well and hold them tight when you glue them.

I used M3 x 8mm button cap screws for all the mounts. 6 for each carriage. The balls are 9.5mm (3/8th in) ball bearings with an m3 hole drilled and tapped.

The spacing between the balls is 40mm.
I am still working on the effector and arm designs.

Any questions or need some help drop me a line.
Updated 8-26-2017
added 10mm Ball stud ver for 48mm and 50mm Spacing

Updated:8-3-2016
Add 50mm and 48mm ball spacing.

Updated:12-15-2016
Updated the License and added more tags

UPDATED:12-15-2016
Added STEP files and removed duplicate models.

UPDATE: 9-29-2016
Trimmed off one corner of the belt clamp to improve arm reach.
Added a 43mm Ball spacing design

description.text:
So this is a mount I printed for my friend's quad so he could attach his Xiaomi yi to his quad at an angle so he could get nice flight footage. A previous version of this design broke pretty easily with about 20% infill, so I'd recommend printing at 50% infill. Granted this was PLA, but still. He's having radio issues and hasn't been able to fly much, but I think this v2 design should be better than our first attempt that didn't fit the camera very well.

You may notice that the front corner in the photos is chamfered, that is not by design. My friend had to Dremel that bit out in order for it to fit his frame properly.

Notes:

Don't print with support.
I like to take a file and grind out all the strings that are on the overhangs for the straps, but your printer may do a better job than mine at overhangs and this may not be necessary.

I needed a rubber door stopper to keep my kitchen door from denting the side of my stainless-steel/gray refrigerator.  I couldn't really find anything other than some ugly white stick-on ones at the hardware store.  I wanted something gray that would blend in.....so I made one.  I used my Thing-o-matic to 3D print a negative mold of the final shape, then I formed the doorstop itself using sillicone rubber (or homemade Sugru.   See my instructions below.  
I do not expect anyone to actually make an copy of this, but maybe serve as inspiration of other things you can make using your 3D plastic printer that are not plastic.  I find my printer so handy to make things for around the house.

I included a series of pictures above to try to show my steps. First off, I had some Sugru packages around that I was going to use, but when I opened them up, I found out they were already expired and cured. :( I hate buying things with such short expiration dates. I found instructions on-line for making your own Sugru substiute using regular silicone caulk and corn starch. I was able to tint it with some acylic paints and it worked great. I was surprised how easy it was to make and quickly it cured (within 20 minutes it was fully cured an no "silicone smell"). http://www.instructables.com/id/How-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute/ I found the best way to mold the "sugru" was to use a rubber glove as a release liner, pulled into the mold with a vacuum....I drilled a small hole in the bottom of my mold and sucked it down with my shop vac. The thin rubber glove is very elastic and gives a smooth surface finish. I then mixed my "sugru" and mushed it into my mold filling it up. I had to be very careful not to trap any air bubbles or they would end of up on the finished product. I made multiple pieces before I figuired out the exact technique. Once I had a finished piece I was happy with, I mixed up a tiny more of my "sugru" and used it to stick the door stop to the side of my fridge. It has stuck in place perfectly for the past year and looks/works great.

comments.text: Rubber door stops helps the door not to be opened too widely. It is available in EPDM, silicone, NBR, SBR,Zinc Alloy,etc. These rubber stoppers are also manufactured using rubber foam. Rubber door stoppers prevents the damages to the doors. They comes with good elasticity too. Some of the other types of rubber door stoppers are Solid/compact Extrusion, Co-extruded seal strip, PVC&Rubber compound extrusion.

description.text:
12x 9G micro servos used. The idea is to use all digital pins on Arduino from 2~13 and keep pin 0 and 1 for communication. The leg is designed with replaceable plate so I can design the different look of the leg without replace servos all over again. Video 1:
http://youtu.be/lNeNtL1E-SI Video 2:
http://youtu.be/SCRc4YMtu8c Video 3(Complete):
http://youtu.be/3NyIRfgOr8s

For those parts you need to print put:
bodyPlate_top x 1
bodyPlate_bottom x 1
legShield x 6
arm x 6
link x 6
connx x 6
bracket_L x 3
bracket_R x 3 You want to buy M2 or M3 bolts and nylon nuts for joints connections(i.e. connx.stl and link.stl). Also get those hobby aluminum tubes and cut them into proper length. Check the image I have also upload at gallery for better understanding. There are 3 places need to use this combination.
  • connx.stl and link.stl
  • connx.stl and arm.stl
  • bracket_L(R).stl and link.stl
    You might want to check the image for reference.
    • in addition:
    For head and the pack parts are not nesseary but I still add it for someone who might interested. They are actuallyvery rough designed because they just add up for fun personally. So you might need some crazy glue or 3M double sided type to support some joints. Those parts are:
    head.stl
    neck.stl
    *topSideCover.stl For battery I have used 7.4v 500mah Lipo. You may search ebay by keywords:"dlg 500mah 50c 7.4v" to find the exact battery that I used. For LED holder you may search ebay by:"5mm LED mount holder". The size should be pretty much the same on "head.stl".

title: Spool holder for 30 to 55 mm centerhole spools

description.text:
Uses two 608ZZ (roller skate) bearings for one side, so total 4 bearings are needed for two cones.
Created one of my own after one spool dropped down on the print head (I have a large delta with spool attached on top of it), causing the print head to lose it's position and a failed print, of course. The reason for this was, because previous holders were slowly "unscrewing" the 8mm threaded rod (used as axis for the holders) - the plastic part was touching the rod, thus creating slight drag.
Slots to ease the installation of bearings. There's a small ridge to keep the bearing in place. Either nuts or small clips to be added to keep the cones pushing itself apart.
Small fillets on edges, (especially on bottom edges) to help getting parts off the print surface. I alwas have a lot of trouble with it because of the buildtak surface.

description.text: CrashSpace is a Los Angeles Hackerspace (Culver City actually). This is a version of the logo generated by tracing the b&w image in sketchup and extruding, then running it through SkeinForge (SkeinFox actually) to create the GCode for printing on my Makerbot (Goldbot). The Gcode is set to print at 245degC with a raft, because thats what works on Goldbot. If you want something different, run it through skeinforge again.

title: Anet a8 auto leveling plate with / without standoffs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original auto leveling plate for this printer is a piece of S**T!, so i've made my own upgraded model :)

Just print and use :P

UPDATE
Due to request i have added version without standoffs :P Enjoy

comments.text: If I understood properly this is just works the same as "hardware endstop". You have to adjust it mannually and tune it by "z offset" option in firmware. But this is not good sensor at all. I have tried almost every sensor on the market and finished in BLtouch sensor. So if You do not have it already cosider bltouch. Other models are something like waste of money. Works good for bed curve adjusting, but not as z endstop.
comments.author: pparsniak

comments.text: I would  just  like to ask..... how do you find the AL sensor as a viable option and  - once setup - does it  hold the configuration or does it  need regulate resetting?   Hoping to escape the sarcasm and  moronic answer off a FaceBook question :)

where do i start to put the probe with this plate ?

title: Moto 360  back cover.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you broke the Moto 360, do not try to look for the parts in the shop.
Now you can download and print it!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Step 1.

First you need to disassemble the watch and to get rid of the old building

Step 2.

Then cut the wall of the heart rate sensor of clear plastic.

Step 3.

Glue wall using dichloromethane or superglue. I printed out the PLA plastic, so the pasted dichloromethane.

Be careful, do not fall glue clear plastic part. Step 4.

To maintain body integrity, I was using a clerical gum.

Step 5.

Glue NFC module.

Step 6

Installing the motherboard.

Step 7.

And assemble all the parts together.

Be careful, the wires are very fragile. PS.

The holes for the strap and the microphone were made hot clip.

print_settings.Notes:: ENJOY!

title: Savings manager container
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello there!

The following is a project for my MSc on Strategic Product Design

Have you ever tried to save money for more than one purposes?

"The regulator" can manage up to 3 savings regarding your needs.

Easy to create, easy to assemble.

I wanted to make a fast and efficient printing. For that reason all the parts are in general rectangular and they don't need any support (depends on the printer you are using)

My restrictions were for the object not to exceed 12X12X12 cm in total

*The sooner I print the model I will upload it

Thank you in advance!

Happy printing!

Printer:

Flux DELTA

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

15-30 %

Notes:

For assembling the final container please follow the instructions given on the picture.

Place the BOX_case on top of a table.
Put inside the BOX_case the LARGE_box and place on top of it the LARGE_box_cap.
Continuous place the MEDIUM_box and the SMALL_box as shown on the picture.

Close the BOX_container by its BOX_cap.

You are now ready to save some money!!

  • additional and for your convenience, place on the upper side next to each hole, stickers with the purpose of its saving!

ENJOY!

title: Glow sphere #1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I love the look of gavi's Spherical lattice here on Thingiverse, but don't have a resin printer to get the beautiful print that they do. However, their low-res "visualization only" file is small enough to open in Tinkercad, so I sandwiched it between two spherical layers and printed in translucent filament as an LED light cover. The model is built to fit around a twist-on battery LED assembly I found on amazon.com (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0040ICQVO/ref=oh_details_o06_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) MakerHome Day 68: http://makerhome.blogspot.com/2013/11/day-68-glow-sphere-1.html =====

Seeing a few of these on here, I noted there wasn't really something properly designed for the iPhone 5. I've designed mine to fit my 5 with otterbox case, so it will be a nice fit. I've added a stand bit at the back, and the entire assembly is toleranced to hopefully!! fit by inserting male ends into female ends. I'm currently printing this at the time of writing, so I will add photos when it's all assembled!  
Print notes - for some reason, the dimensions get lost between inventor and the STL export. All you need to do is scale all parts up to 1000% in Makerware or your respective slicers. I prefer Makerware because it allows me to manipulate in 3d, what I've done  is sat the speaker bigger-end down, and everything on its' side. There will need to be support materials.
Print 2x each speaker, one stand and 2x bendy bit. Assemble at any angle you wish.

title: Holder for 12V to 5V Power Converter Guts

description.text:
Chopped it up a bit to fit a small cig lighter power converter guts. Its small enough that it really only needed three tabs. This will be mounted to the side of a Deltaprintr to power a neopixel array and the arduino nano that controls it.

I doubt anyone else will have the same form factor as I do but you can at least use the enclosed file as a starting point.

The width of the board space is 15.5mm (so your board should be slightly wider than this, or you can use some hot glue to secure)

The length of the board space is 24.6mm -- if your board is longer than this it will stick out the end (which I did on purpose but be aware)

author: APing

title: tesseract 4.25 x 4.25 x 5.00 inch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A 3d represntation of a 4 dimensional cube The formula to create one of these is actually very simple, or I should to create an X dimensional one. In simple terms a 2 dimensional cube is a square and how you do it is to draw a single line (calli it segment 1) and call its base Point 0 draw another line that is 90 degrees (call this one segment 2) to the original so it originates from Point 0, then move to the end of a given segment and figure out which segments have not be drawn yet at the end of the segment you are currently on. So for starting on segment one and going from point 0 up to the end of that segment you have not drawn segment 2 so go ahead and draw it then go back to point 0 and go down the first segment 2 to its end and the only segment you have not drawn on that path is segment one so draw it. so here how it works in shorthand
start at point zero
draw segment 1 vertically
go back to point zero
draw new segment 90 degrees from first segment this is segment 2
you should have an "L" shape
now go back to Point 0 and move along the path of segment one to its end and since on this path youhave only drawn segment 1 now draw teh missing segment, segment 2, here. Now you should have a "C" shape Go back to point 0 since all the segments are now drawn on the first path we checked go to the other path, the first segment 2 you drew.starting at point 0 move along segment 2 to its end and draw teh remaining segment you haven't drawn on this path which is segment 1.
you should now have a squareor a two dimensional cube. Now here is where your mind comes into play everyone has seen the 3 dimensional wire drawing of a cube and we all know that the diagonal line is to be assumed at a 90 degree angle from theother two line just in perspective the same is done here to go into higher dimensional cubes
For each direction a new line segment is added each to be assumed is at 90 degree from the others that si wher our mind has to leap to but the methodology remains exactly the same. The first two lines are easily seen as 90 degree off from eachother the others are not and that makes drawing them tricky actually modleing them on a computer is much fast and easier, So enjoy this one and once printed put it on a slowing spinning platdorm and it will be neat to watch Added one pic to show it with supports

I printed this in PLA at 200 microns at full size so it is 4.25 x 4.25 x 5 not quite a square but close and I used supports and it took a long time 34 hours at my speed and it had a LOT of support but it turned out great I have also printed ones at have size without support and they were much faster but some looping of the lines did occur

description.text: Ask the ultimate question. Show me what you got! I want to see what you got!

Printer:

P3Steel (modified Migbot) Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Base was printed at .3mm.

Instructions

All non-painted parts were glued with Gorilla super glue gel. All painted parts were glued with Loctite GO2 glue. I've been using GO2 glue for some time and it always works with painted parts. The draw back is it takes 24 hours for it to fully cure. I provided a hanger to glue on the back (which doesn't have to be painted) so you can use super glue. You will probably have to ream out the text mounting holes with a small drill bit for them to fit. sorry.

title: Light #008 - 3d-printed 2 parts lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Multi-functional lamp consisting of two 3D printed parts (assembled without glue). The lamp can be used as a table lamp, wall lamp or ceiling lamp.
Total lamp height approx. 250 mm (9.8 inch), diameter base approx. 170 mm (6.7 inch).
Only suitable for E14 fitting and small led-bulbs with threaded fitting, 2.5 à 3.5 W.

Base element is printed in PLA, infill approx. 25%, shell 2 perimeters, top/bottom 3-4 layers.
Lampshade is printed with transparent PETG infill only (without shell/top/bottom). You can experiment with the infill in Cura, Slic3r or Simplify 3d to get what you want. The coarse fabric in the picture is made with Slic3r 20% honeycomb. The fine fabric is made in Cura 20% lines.
Layer height 0.2 for the shade is sufficient. No support needed.

For more information and other lamp designs: http://www.sjaakvandervooren.nl/index.php/en/3d
